SUBJECT:
Call for Nominations to CSBA Delegate Assembly
	 
	 
The California School Boards Association (CSBA) is currently accepting nominations for the CSBA Delegate Assembly.  Any CSBA member board is eligible to nominate board members within their geographical region or subregion.  Boards may nominate as many individuals as it chooses by using the nomination form, which includes obtaining approval from board member(s) being nominated to CSBA's Delegate Assembly.
	 
All nominees must submit a one-page, single-sided, candidate biographical sketch form and an optional one-page, one-sided resume (resume cannot be substituted for the candidate biographical sketch form).  All nominations must be postmarked no later than Monday, January 7, 2013.  Faxes are also acceptable, but must be received by January 7, 2013.  
	 
Delegates serve  two-year terms, beginning April 1, 2013, through March 31, 2015.  There are two required Delegate Assembly meetings each year, one in May in Sacramento and one preceding the CSBA Annual Education Conference and Trade Show in November/December.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of KIPP San Jose Collegiate Charter Renewal Petition
	 
BACKGROUND
Public Charter Schools are approved initially for up to a five (5) year period and at the end of that time must apply for a charter school renewal for a term of five (5) years and continue to apply for renewal after each five (5) year term. Pursuant to Education Code 47605, a public hearing is required within thirty (30) days following the submission of a renewal charter school petition to the district.  The renewal petition was submitted to the Board on October 18, 2012.
	 
During the Public Hearing, the Governing Board of the school district considered the level of support for the petition by the teachers employed by the district, other employees of the district and parents. The public hearing was held during the November 15, 2012 meeting where KIPP gave a presentation and had many supporters in attendance.   The Governing Board shall either grant or deny the charter renewal within sixty (60) days of receipt of the petition. The decision will be made at the December 11, 2012 Board Meeting.
	 
KIPP San Jose Collegiate is a 9th through 12th grade school, with a focus on college readiness.  KIPP serves about 400 students from diverse backgrounds with 95% minority students and 70% qualify for free or reduced lunch.  KIPP first opened its doors in East Side in 2008 and is going through their first renewal.  One hundred percent of the class of 2012 were college ready and 95% were accepted to a four year postsecondary institution.
	 
A team of district experts from the Instructional Division, Business Division, and Human Resources Division reviewed the charter renewal proposal and visited the school site. Their findings are included in the renewal matrix. 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable

Not Applicable
 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the renewal of KIPP San Jose Collegiate charter.  The charter will be renewed for 5 years and will expire, June 30, 2018.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education Students
	 
DESCRIPTION:  
Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student's parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CASHEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CASHEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:
An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.

SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action of the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act (CUPCCAA)
		 
		 
The California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act (CUPCCAA) is a program created in 1983 by the State Legislature, which allows local agencies to perform public project work with alternative bidding procedures that expedite public works projects, yet maintains the spirit of open accountability.
		 
A local agency that has adopted CUPCCAA may procure public works projects as follows:
		 
(a) Public projects of $45,000 or less may be performed by negotiated contract or by purchase order (PCC 22032(a)). 
(b) Public projects of $175,000 or less may be let to contract by the informal procedures set forth in the Act (PCC 22032(b)).
(c) Public projects of more than $175,000 shall be let to contract by formal bidding procedures (PCC 22032(c)). 
		 
Every five years, the Commission shall consider whether there have been material changes in public construction costs and make recommendations to the State Controller regarding adjustments to the bidding procedure monetary limits (PCC 22020).  The most recent adjustment was made by the State Controller effective July 1, 2011.
		 
CUPCCAA simplifies the bidding process for small projects, speeds up contract award, improves timeliness of project completion, simplifies and decreases the cost of administration, and delivers repaired and/or improved teaching and learning facilities to students and staff sooner.
		 
Local school agencies that have adopted CUPCCAA include Alum Rock Union Elementary School District, Evergreen School District, Franklin-McKinley School District, Los Gatos-Saratoga High School District, Milpitas Unified School District, Oak Grove Elementary School District, San Jose Unified School District, Santa Clara Unified School District.  Many, many more school, college, municipal, county and special agencies have also adopted CUPCCAA.
		 
CUPCCAA is a voluntary program. A local agency becomes subject to CUPCCAA by adopting a resolution to become subject to CUPCCAA and filing a copy of the resolution with the State Controller's Office (PCC 22030).  An agency may withdraw at any time by filing a resolution of this election with the State Controller's Office.  There is no cost for adoption of CUPCCAA.
